turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well. I can't stay.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Do you have my work number?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I get real busy between two and four.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: CYTNHIA
turns.text: Did he ask me to take my clothes off? No, he didn't.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Did you take your clothes off?

turns.speaker: CYTNHIA
turns.text: No, I touched me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Wait a minute. Do you mean... don't tell me you... in front of him.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I wish you'd get an answering machine.

turns.speaker: CYTNHIA
turns.text: There's a phone here.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It was busy.

turns.speaker: CYTNHIA
turns.text: Well, why would she want a sun dress? She's got spots on her shoulders and varicose veins.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So will you, someday.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I'm Cynthia Bishop.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do I know you?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I'm Ann Millaney's sister.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: The extrovert.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: She must have been in a good mood when she said that. She usually calls me loud.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: She called you that, too. May I ask why you're here?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: You want me to leave?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I just want to know why you're here.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, like I said, Ann is my sister. Sisters talk. You can imagine the rest.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, I really can't. I find it healthy never to characterize people I don't know or conversations I haven't heard. I don't know what you and your sister discussed about me or anything else. Last time I saw Ann she left here very... confused, I would say. And upset.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: She still is.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: And are you here to berate me for making her that way?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: She didn't tell you why she was upset?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: She didn't give you my address?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: How did you find me?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I, uh, know a guy at the power company.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't understand. Why did you want to come here? I mean, I can't imagine Ann painted a very flattering portrait of me.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, I don't really listen to her when it comes to men. I mean, look at John, for crissake. Oh, you went to school with him didn't you? You're probably friends or something.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Nope. I think the man is a liar.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I think you're right. So come on, I came all the way over here to find out what got Ann so spooked, tell me what happened.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Spooked.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Oh, okay. I think I get it.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What do you get?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, they must be something sexual, because Ann gets freaked out by that shit. Are these tapes of you having sex with these girls or something?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Not exactly.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, either you are or you aren't. Which is it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Why don't you let me tape you?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Doing what?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Talking.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Sex. Your sexual history, your sexual preferences.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What makes you think I'd discuss that with you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: You just want to ask me questions?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I just want to ask you questions.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: And that's all?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's all.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Is this how you get off or something? Taping women talking about their sexual experiences?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Would anybody else see the tape?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Absolutely not. They are for my private use only.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: How do we start?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I turn on the camera. You start talking.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: And you ask questions, right?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: How long will it take?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That depends on you. One woman only used three minutes. Another filled up three two hour tapes.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Can I see some of the other tapes to get an idea of what --

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Do I sit or stand?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Whichever you prefer.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I'd rather sit. Are you ready?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Just a moment.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I am now recording. Tell me your name.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Cynthia Patrice Bishop.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Describe for me your first sexual experience.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: My first sexual experience or the first time I had intercourse?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Your first sexual experience.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I was... eight years old. Michael Green, who was also eight, asked if he could watch me take a pee. I said he could if I could watch him take one, too. He said okay, and then we went into the woods behind our house. I got this feeling he was chickening out because he kept saying, "Ladies first!" So I pulled down my underpants and urinated, and he ran away before I even finished.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Was it ever a topic of conversation between the two of you afterward?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No. He kind of avoided me for the rest of the summer, and then his family moved away. To Cleveland, actually.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: How unfortunate. So when did you finally get to see a penis?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: When I was fourteen.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Live, or in a photograph or film of some sort?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Very much live.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What did you think? Did it look like you expected?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Not really. I didn't picture it with veins or ridges or anything, I thought it would be smooth, like a test tube.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Were you disappointed?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No. If anything, after I looked at it awhile, it got more interesting. It had character, you know?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What about when you touched it? What did you expect it to feel like, and then what did it really feel like?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: It was warmer than I thought it would be, and the skin was softer than it looked. It's weird. Thinking about it now, the organ itself seemed like a separate thing, a separate entity to me. I mean, after he pulled it out and I could look at it and touch it, I completely forgot that there was a guy attached to it. I remember literally being startled when the guy spoke to me.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: He said that my hand felt good.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Then what happened?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Then I started moving my hand, and then he stopped talking.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Would you like me to take my pants off?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: If you wish.  You're not wearing any underwear.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Do you like the way I look?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Do you think I'm pretty?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Prettier than Ann?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Different.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: John doesn't have sex with Ann anymore.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Is that what he tells you?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: He doesn't have to tell me.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Look, I'm just going to come right out and tell you why I'm here, okay?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I'd like to make another tape.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No? Not even one more?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I never do more than one. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I can't talk you into it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No. You'll have to get somebody else.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Now who the hell is going to do that for me?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm sure a substantial number of men in this town would volunteer.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: But I want you to do it, I want somebody who will ask the right questions and everything, somebody I can play to and feel safe because you can't do anything.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Ouch. Okay, I deserved that. Cynthia, don't you understand? After the first time it's just not spontaneous. There's no edge anymore. Look at the tapes, there is only one date on each label. I have never taped anyone twice.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: So make an exception.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: How about if you record over the one we already made? You could have the same date and not use another tape. Who would know?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I would.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, what the hell am I supposed to do?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Cynthia, I don't know.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I can't believe you're doing this after I let you tape me.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm sorry. I can't do it.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Goddamit, give me my tape, then.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I've got to get back to the office.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I only get one today? Gee, how exciting.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I can't let my lunch hour go on too long. I've already skipped one meeting.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Don't give me this passive/aggressive bullshit. If you want to leave, leave. My life doesn't stop when you walk out the door, you know what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I have a friend coming in from out of town, I'll probably be spending some time with him the next couple of days.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Meaning we'll have to cool it for awhile, right?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I wish you'd quit that bartending job.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I hate the thought of guys hitting on you all the time.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I can handle it. Besides, the money is good and some of the guys are cute. And you are in no position to be jealous.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Who said I was jealous?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I wish I could tell everybody that Ann's a lousy lay. Beautiful, popular, Ann Bishop Millaney.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Could be risky.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, maybe I could just start a rumor, then.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, I mean doing it at my house.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Afraid of getting caught?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: You should be. Can I meet this friend of yours?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Cynthia, I don't think you want to, I mean, you should see the way he dresses. I really think he's in a bad way.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I'm intrigued.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You're intrigued?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Sure. Maybe he's the man I'm looking for. Then I won't have to fuck worried husbands all the time.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Cynthia. John. Meet me at my house in exactly one hour.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: You are scum. I'll be there.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: John?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: In here!!

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Cynthia. John.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Not today. I've got other plans.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh.  Well, when, then?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: How about inviting me over to dinner?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You know what I mean.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Yeah, I know what you mean.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: John Millaney.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I want to see you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Right now.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus, I don't know if I can get away. I've got a client waiting. I'd have to do some heavy duty juggling.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Then get those balls in the air and get your butt over here.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Cynthia. John.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, this is timely. Your wife is here, would you like to speak to her?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: She's there? What's she doing there?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I don't know. I'm not sure I can duplicate the level of intensity I had the other day.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Nothing wrong with trying.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I don't think my sister would agree.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Do you want me to stop calling?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Look, I'll call you, okay?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's just so blatantly stupid, I have a hard time believing you did it.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What's so stupid about it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That you... you don't even know the guy.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, you know him, he's a friend of yours, do you think he can be trusted?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Shit, after what you've told me, I don't know. I should've known, when he showed up dressed like some arty brat.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I like the way he dresses.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What if this tape gets into the wrong hands?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: "The wrong hands"? We're not talking about military secrets, John. They're just tapes that he makes so he can sit around and get off.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus Christ. And he doesn't have sex with any of them? They just talk?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus. I could almost understand it if he was screwing these people, almost. Why doesn't he just buy some magazines or porno movies or something?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Doesn't work. He has to know the people, he has to be able to interact with them.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Interact, fine, but did you have to masturbate in front of him, for God's sake? I mean...

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I felt like it, so what? Goddam, you and Ann make such a big deal out of it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You told Ann about this?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Of course. She is my sister. I tell her almost everything.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I wish you hadn't done that.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's just something I'd prefer she didn't know about.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: She's a grown-up, she can handle it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I just... Ann is very...

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Hung up.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It just wasn't a smart thing to do. Did you sign any sort of paper, or did he have any contract with you saying he wouldn't broadcast these tapes?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You realize you have no recourse legally? This stuff could show up anywhere.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: It won't. I trust him.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You trust him.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Yeah, I do. A helluva lot more than I trust you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Exactly what I said. I'd trust him before I'd trust you. How much clearer can I be?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It hurts that you would say that to me.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Oh, please. Come on, John. You're fucking your wife's sister and you hardly been married a year. You're a liar. But at least I know you're a liar. It's the people that don't know, like Ann, that have to watch out.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: By definition you're lying to Ann, too.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: That's right. But I never took a vow in front of God and everybody to be "faithful" to my sister.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, are we going to do it or not?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Actually, no, I've changed my mind. I shouldn't have called.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, I'm here now. I'd like to do something...

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: How about straightening up the living room?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Come on, John. You should be happy, we've gone this far without Ann finding out, I'm making it real easy on you. Just walk out of here and I'll see you at your house for a family dinner sometime.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Did he put you up to this?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Graham.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No, he didn't put me up to this. Jesus, I don't need people to tell me what I should do. I've just been thinking about things, that's all.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I can't believe I let him stay in my house. Right under my nose. That deviant fucker was right under my nose and I didn't see him.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: If he had been under your prick you'd have spotted him for sure.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: God, you... you're mean.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I know. Will you please leave now?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Maybe I don't want to leave. Maybe I want to talk.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: John, we have nothing to talk about.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I knew it, I knew it. Things are getting complicated.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No, John, things are getting real simple.

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: Plenty of room for two people.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It'll just be me.

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: Student?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.  You said three-fifty?

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: Plus first and last month deposit.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Will you lease month-to-month?

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: Not for three-fifty.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: How about for five hundred?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Everybody has a past.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What do you think the Greeks would make of that outfit you're wearing?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: A bonfire, probably.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, it's not bad. Usually Ann has some serious salt action going. I keep telling her, you can always add more if you want, but you can't take it out.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You have family here also?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm sorry. Am I prying again?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You were prying before?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes, this afternoon. I was grilling Ann about your marriage this afternoon.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Really. How'd it go?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: She held up very well.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I wish I didn't have to live someplace.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Get rid of the car when you get your apartment, then you'll still have one key.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I like having the car, the car is important.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Especially if you want to leave someplace in a hurry.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Or go someplace in a hurry.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hi, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Where are the tapes, Graham?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What tapes?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You know which tapes! Where are they?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: John, as a lawyer, you should know that those tapes are private property.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: So is my wife, asshole!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: She's not property, John, she's a person. Were you just going to keep right on lying to her?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What the hell do you think? I love Ann. You think I'm going to tell her about Cynthia and hurt her feelings like that?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: God, you need help.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I need help? Whose sitting by himself in a room choking his chauncey to a bunch of videotapes, Graham? Not me, buddy. You're the fucking nut. Now show me those tapes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm not kidding, Graham, you'd better do what I say. Give me those tapes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Graham, I swear to Christ I'll kill your scrawny ass. Now give me those tapes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Give me your keys.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: My keys?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Your keys, asshole!! Your two fucking keys!! Give them to me!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm not going to give you my keys.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Have you ever wanted to make love to someone other than your husband?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Goddamit...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Answer him, goddammit!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You're hesitating. I think that means you have.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Shut up!!!

turns.speaker: VOICE ON PHONE
turns.text: IBM.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Brian Kirkland, please.

turns.speaker: VOICE ON PHONE
turns.text: May I ask who's calling?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: John Millaney.

turns.speaker: VOICE ON PHONE
turns.text: One moment.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Anyway, I've always said, the work is the thing. I can be happy without a marriage, but take away my work, that's different. And if Ann can't handle that, that's her problem, like we re all alone in this world, you know what I'm saying? I mean, fuck.  Jesus, what's takin' this guy?

turns.speaker: VOICE ON PHONE
turns.text: Mr. Millaney?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: VOICE ON PHONE
turns.text: Mr. Kirkland has asked me to inform you that he has obtained legal representation elsewhere, and that if you have a message for him to leave it with me.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Mr. Millaney?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Mr. Forman would like to see you in his office.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Okay, in a minute, I'm on with a client.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: He said immediately.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: All right, jesus.

turns.speaker: BETTS
turns.text: ...probably nothing at all. It's probably just a bunch of, I don't know, fatty cysts. You can have them removed in a doctor's office. Has Nick seen a doctor?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: He hates doctors. Doctors and lawyers. He never goes to doctors.

turns.speaker: BETTS
turns.text: Well, look. How's this? You go on down to the clinic and tell that nice Dr. St. Luc...  ...you tell him that Nick's ill, he's got these lumps, and he can't get out of bed. Tell him to come when you're sure Nick'll be home. And don't tell Nick anything. Let the two of them fight it out.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: He'll be really mad.

turns.speaker: BETTS
turns.text: So? You'll find out what's wrong and then you'll be able to relax a little bit. Let him be the uptight one for a change.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: BETTS
turns.text: Hi. Want a drink?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: No thanks. Just wanted to tell you that Dr. St. Luc is coming up to see Nick at ten or so.

turns.speaker: BETTS
turns.text: Was he nice to you?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Oh, you feel very good, Betts. You have such a cosy body. I'm jealous, I'm so skinny.

turns.speaker: BETTS
turns.text: Make love to me, 'Nine? I want you to make love to me. Please, please make love to me.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: C'mon, let's smoke one of the cigarettes right now. Your father'll never miss it.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I can't, dummy. He'll see that the pack's been opened. You're such a dumbhead.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: OK, then. I'm gonna go back to the store and buy my own pack and smoke 'em all myself.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Buy 'em with what, dumbhead?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: With some milk jugs I just happened to pick up on the way home.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Jesus!

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Let's get outta here before somebody hears us!

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Dr. St. Luc? Detective-Sergeant Heller. I'd like to ask you a few questions.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: You're the one who found the bodies?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Did you touch anything? Move anything before we got here?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: No, nothing.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: You knew these people?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: I knew the man, Emil Hobbes, a doctor and a professor at university. I saw the girl around the building but I didn't know her. She never came to the clinic.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: So you just came up to visit this Hobbes and you found them like that?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Oh, no. I haven't seen Dr. Hobbes since I was in medical school. He taught me... he was my prof in urology and... I think he conducted a few seminars in psychopharmacology. That was it. I had no idea he'd ever set foot in Starliner Towers until today.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: I see. Then what brought you up here?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: It was very strange. He called me at six this morning. Hobbes called me. I thought I was dreaming. I haven't heard that voice for so long. He told me who it was, then he said something like, 'Meet me at apartment 1208 at noon. I want you to go out for lunch with me. It's time you furthered your education.' Then he laughed and hung up. I went back to sleep. He called me again at eight to remind me to come.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: How did he sound this time? Was he nervous? Depressed?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: He sounded fine.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: And that was her. Annabelle Horse... field.

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Far as I know, yeah, that was her.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Is that the man who called you up here?

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Yeah, that's Dr. St. Luc. He's the head of our little medical clinic here.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Medical clinic?

turns.speaker: SUPER
turns.text: Yeah. This is an island, you know? Takes too long to get into the city. We gotta have everything right here or somebody complains.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Well, let's go talk to your doctor.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Mrs. Ementhal's ready and waiting, Doctor.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Mm? OK. Be with you in a sec.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: OK, Roger. Here's the stuff you wanted. Files on Horsefield, Tudor, Swinburne, and Velakofsky. Papers published by Hobbes, Linsky, and Lefebvre in a couple of issues of the Bulletin of the Canadian Medical Association and also the Journal of the American Medical Association. And, as an added extra, a couple of odds and ends from the files I helped compile before your time here, Doctor. I thought they might interest you.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: That's great, Forsythe, great. Thanks.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Do I get a kiss?

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Kiss, kiss?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Uh, OK. Sure.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Another kiss?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: C'mon, Forsythe. Are there any more on the list?

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: No. Dotty's the last.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Roger? If you're going to be staying here anyway, why don't you come up to my place for a late supper?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Meeting Rollo at Tudor's. Might take a while.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Doesn't matter to me how late it is. I can keep it warm.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Anything wrong?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: No. I don't think so.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Well? Supper at my place?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: OK. But late.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Great! Go back to your files. Bye.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Forsythe, Forsythe! What's wrong? What's happened?

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: A man... I think I recognized him... a man who lives here. He just...  ...he just attacked me for no reason at all. I just opened the door... I was making supper for you, and he grabbed me, he tried to kiss me...

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Where is he now? Do you know?

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: I think I... I think I killed him. I stabbed him with something and he fell.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Will you be OK now? I've got to go to your place to see if he's still there. I've got to see if it's... if it's what we both think it is.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: Oh, no! You're not leaving me here all alone. I'm going with you.

turns.speaker: FORSYTHE
turns.text: But where are you going?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Down to the incinerator.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Can I call you at the office?

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: What do you want to call me at the office for?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: I don't know. I just thought I might want to call you. I don't know.

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: I won't be at the office except to sign in.  I've got a lot of claims to check out. All over the place. Garages and more garages.  I'll come home right after work.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: You say something?

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: Nope. Damned thing wriggled out of my hands. That's all.

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: Do you want to make love? You're absolutely beautiful, those eyes, that expression. You're absolutely the most sexy thing alive. Do you want to make love?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Nick, you're so strange...

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: You will make love to me, won't you, Janine? Won't you make love to me? You start it. Won't you? I think I've forgotten how to start.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Oh, Nick, Nick... I can't take this.

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: Please, Janine. Please, pleasepleaseplease, Janine Janine JanineJanineJanine...

turns.speaker: TUDOR
turns.text: Make love to me, make love to me, love, love to me...

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: I want to be able to see us, Nick. I... I'm going to go into the bathroom now and put in my contacts, OK? Is that OK?  I want to be able to see us when we make love, OK?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MR. SPERGAZZI
turns.text: Please pardon me. I am Niccolo Spergazzi. I am a resident here. I don't know... we were walking in the hallway and... Cabiria... my wife... she was attacked by this thing... here, on her arm.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Where is this thing that attacked your wife?

turns.speaker: MR. SPERGAZZI
turns.text: I hit it. I hit it with my cane. Then I carry it on the cane and I throw it down to the incinerator, down to the garbage.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Go back to their apartment with them and treat her for second-degree burns. It'll have to do for now.  What's your number? The number of your apartment?

turns.speaker: MR. SPERGAZZI
turns.text: We live in 703.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: OK. I'll meet you back there. Don't leave until I get there. Lock the door and don't open it except for me. OK?

turns.speaker: MR. SPERGAZZI
turns.text: Yes? Who is there?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: It's Dr. St. Luc, Mr Spergazzi. Let me speak to the nurse, please.

turns.speaker: MR. SPERGAZZI
turns.text: Oh, but the nurse, she went away. I think she must go to look for you.

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: Want me to breathe deeply?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Just breathe normally.

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: Good shape for an old man, eh?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Mr. Parkins, what makes you think you caught these lumps of yours from a young lady?

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: She had a couple just like them. Right here near her belly button. You could push 'em around. I thought they were kinda sexy, myself.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Didn't she ever have these lumps looked at by a doctor?

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: Didn't seem worried about them.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Was this girl from Starliner Towers?

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: Yep. She lived in 1208. But we usually went to my place. Bigger liquor cabinet, bigger bed.  She was gone when I got back from my last Florida trip. Too bad. Had a beautiful tan.  Must have gone home to mother.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Was her name Annabelle Horsefield?

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: That's the one.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: I'm going to send you to the hospital to have a few X-rays taken. I want to find out exactly what you're hiding in there, OK? Give them this. The address is right there under Radiology.

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: Gonna cut me open?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Well, let's wait for the X-rays.

turns.speaker: PARKINS
turns.text: Used to know a doctor who said he got to know his patients better than their wives did.  Cutting a man open sure does expose more of him than pulling down his pants, gotta admit that.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Not exactly the kind of lunch Hobbes would have laid on you, Rog, but it's all I got, and...  ...all I got I share with you. Go ahead. Take all you want.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: You touch my spleen, Rollo.  And here all the time I was thinking -- if I ever bothered to think about the good old days -- well, at least there's Rollo. He's in VD and he's happy.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: I'm still a VD man under the skin, Rog. You know me. I'm a down-to-earth kinda guy, right?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Well, at least you still talk the same.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: So who changes?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: But you gave up your private practice. Suddenly you're into pure research and you... you're what, a parasitologist?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: That was my father's idea... private practice. He wanted to set me up -- I couldn't say no. But he's dead now. And me, I'm still a snoop, I gotta do research. Look at that beautiful stuff...  ...lookit it!

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: I know. You're bored already. Transplants are yesterday's kishkas, right?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Did I say anything?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Look. You got men, you got parasites that live in, on, and around men. Now. Why not breed a parasite that does something useful? Eh? Why not breed a parasite capable of taking over the function of any one of a bunch of human organs? Why not, for example, a parasite living in the human abdominal cavity that plugs into the circulatory system and filters the blood like a kidney? If it takes a little blood for itself, so what? Be generous! You can afford it.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: You put the bug into the body of a man with a diseased kidney, the bug attacks the bad kidney, dissolves it, it's assimilated by the body, and now you got a perfectly good parasite where you used to have a rotten kidney. I know what you're gonna say. You're gonna say it's crazy.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: It's crazy.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Right. It's crazy. But here's the beauty part. Ready?  Who cares?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: You know and I know that Hobbes was a lousy teacher, eh? Lousy. Dry, academic, afraid of women, lousy. But he was always a genius at one thing -- getting grants. Could he get grants for crazy projects?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Rog, I gotta talk serious to you. Really. Listen. Ya listening? OK. I want you to come into this with me. To tell the honest-to-God truth, I'm lonely.  All Hobbes ever did was run around getting money and phone me in the middle of the night. He wanted you in anyway. That's why we were gonna get together, the three of us. We would have enough to keep us going for at least five years, even with inflation.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Rollo, you know me. Once a GP, always a GP.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: You want to help sick people for the rest of your life? God forbid I should talk you out of it.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: You oughta be careful yourself. Might end up cutting your throat.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: It was women did it to Hobbes. Couldn't handle them. That girl, that Annabelle -- talk about crazy projects.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Who was she?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Aw, he met her when he was lecturing at some private girls' school. They caught him examining her little tits for breast cancer in the faculty lounge. She was twelve. Don't ask. It was craziness, believe me.  They used to come here sometimes.  Don't ask.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: But you'll think about what I said about working together, huh?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: OK. I'll think about it.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: That you, Rog?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: It's me, Rollo Linsky. Remember me?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Rollo! How'sa boy? I was just thinking about you.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Yeah, well, I'm flattered, but you won't find any real meat in them.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: No? How come?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Listen, Rog. I knew Hobbes was funny, you know? I told you that. But I didn't really know just how funny he was. See... when he kicked off, they sent all the personal secret stuff they found to his mother -- she's still alive but just barely -- and she sent everything she thought was medical to me here at the lab. I'm Hobbes's partner, right?  Anyway, I've been going through his papers, and what they add up to is this: Hobbes was shafting us all, me, the university, the foundations and the councils, the private labs, everybody. We never really knew what it was we were working on. Hobbes gave us each a few crumbs, but he was the only one who knew what the whole loaf would look like.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: OK, I bite. What does it look like?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: It looks like -- and I quote -- 'a disease to save man from his mind.'

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Lemme clarify for you.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: He didn't make it.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Maybe Hobbes didn't know it, but Annabelle was a pretty popular girl around Starliner Towers. I've got three men here, maybe four, who're hosting large, free-moving, apparently pathogenic, abdominal growths that nobody I've tried can identify. You were next on my list.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: I'd kinda like to come over there and have a look at one of these guys.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: I've got a date with one of them at ten. Can you make it?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: Yeah.  Ah, I don't want to panic you or anything, but, I mean, the way Hobbes designed them, they're supposed to get out of hand real quick, so you don't have much time to think about what's happening to you. Once they decide to start pumping all those dynamite juices into the old blood stream... I dunno. But if you see some people doing kind of compulsive, maybe even bizarre sexual things...

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: Yeah? What do I do then?

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: I dunno. Try tranquilizers. Once you can get at them, there's a lotta stuff you can use. I'll bring a bagful. It's just the standard tropical kit. But the trick is to get at them.

turns.speaker: ST. LUC
turns.text: OK. It's apartment 1009, South Tower, Starliner Towers. May as well go there directly.

turns.speaker: ROLLO
turns.text: OK, Rog. See you at ten.

turns.speaker: ANSALONG
turns.text: NIGHT NIGHT

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: NIGHT NIGHT

turns.speaker: ANSALONG
turns.text: IT'S TIME FOR BYE-BYES IT'S BEEN A GREAT DAY THANKS A HEAP NOW IT'S TIME FOR EVERYONE TO GO TO SLEEP

turns.speaker: ANSALONG
turns.text: GOT THE HOT FLUSH SYMPTOMS AND I'M FEELING FREAKY

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: YOUNG MALE INTERN, TALL AND HANDSOME

turns.speaker: ANSALONG
turns.text: GOT MY HEM SO HIGH THEY'LL SAY I'M BEING CHEEKY

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: WITH LEGS LIKE MINE I'M REALLY MADE FOR DANCING

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: BREAKING OUT

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: BREAKING OUT

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: BREAKING OUT

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: BREAKING OUT

turns.speaker: OSCAR
turns.text: BREAKING OUT

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: BREAKING OUT

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: You bet, Bert.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Good!  I'm gonna be there.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Later, Brenda.  Ah, Bert, could you spare a moment?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: How's Brad?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: A wreck.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Check.  The quacks are willing tools?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Fools!

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: I wouldn't mind doing Janet one or two favours.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Time to check with Flavors.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Sank you!  Velcome!  Sank you!

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: What's cookin', Bert?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I tell you what's cooking.  She made the blind see and it was a gift!  Who was it from?  Let's hear an 'F" for...

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: They should be sent to the Danube before Dawn.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Nothing.  Just...memories!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: About Brad's family?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: As Janet's parents this should be really easy.  Your last clue... Mental Instability.  You have thirty seconds.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You got it!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I got it!  I got it!!!

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Congratulations!  It's 'Happy Homes' for Harry and Emily Weiss of Denton.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Infantile regression.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You got it!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I got it!  I got it!!!

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Introduce yourselves.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I'm Janet Majors and this is my husband Brad.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: We've been hearing some bad things about you, Brad.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: He needs help.
